core.name: core
core.description: Contains core utility functions and classes.

Li.name: Li
Li.description: Contains useful and most frequently used functions.

Li.Publisher.name: Li.Publisher
Li.Publisher.description:
Base class for Publishers.
This class helps you to achieve the Observer (also known as publisher-subscriber) design pattern.
Your class prototype may have a property named 'eventTypes' which is a list (i.e array) of eventTypes that the class as a publisher would/can trigger.

classitems.description:
Browser information. This object has 3 sub-properties: name, version and OS.
Overrides jQuery.browser. You also get three 'is' prefixed boolean properties attached to Li:
1. for OS (e.g Li.isWindows), 2. for browser vendor (e.g Li.isIE), and 3. vendor+version (e.g Li.isIE8).
classitems.name: browser

classitems.description: DOM utility methods

Given a DOM node, this method finds the next tag/node that would appear in the dom.
WARNING: Do not remove or add nodes while traversing, because it could cause the traversal logic to go crazy.

params.name: node
params.description: Could be a any node (element node or text node)

params.name: ancestor
params.description:
Node An ancestorial element that can be used to limit the search.
The search algorithm, while traversing the ancestorial heirarcy, will not go past/above this element.

params.name: callback
params.description:
A callback called on each element traversed.

callback gets following parameters:
node: Current node being traversed.
isOpenTag: boolean. On true, node would be the next open tag/node that one would find when going
linearly downwards through the DOM. Filtering with isOpenTag=true, one would get exactly what native TreeWalker does.
Similarly isOpenTag=false when a close tag is encountered when traversing the DOM. AFAIK TreeWalker doesn't give this info.

callback can return one of the following values (with their meanings):
'halt': Stops immediately and returns null.
'return': Halts and returns node.
'continue': Skips further traversal of current node (i.e won't traverse it's child nodes).
'break': Skips all sibling elements of current node and goes to it's parent node.

relation: The relation compared to the previously traversed node.

params.name: scope
params.description: Value of 'this' keyword within callback

classitems.name: traverse

classitems.description: Converts DOM to HTML string
classitems.name: toHTML

classitems.description: jQuery's index() method doesn't return the child index properly for non-element nodes (like text node, comment).
classitems.name: childIndex

classitems.description: Extra utility methods

Move properties from one object to another.
Property is only moved if source.hasOwnProperty(property) is true.

params.name: target
params.description: Object to which properties are to be moved

params.name: source
params.description: Object from which properties are to moved.

params.name: props
params.description: Array of properties to move.

classitems.name: move

classitems.description: Delete undefined properties from object

Checks if 'ancestor' is ancestor of 'descendent'.
This is still needed because IE10's element.contains is buggy sometimes.

return.description:
Returns true if 'ancestor' is indeed the ancestor of 'descendent'.
Also returns true if ancestor == descendent.

classitems.name: contains

classitems.description:
Lithium - Utilities that jQuery doesn't have.
Intended to be used along with jQuery.
MIT License
Checks whether a variable is defined.
classitems.name: isDefined

classitems.description:
Returns true for all values that are of type 'boolean'
Note that booleans declared with 'new' keyword are objects and aren't considered "boolean"s.
classitems.name: isBoolean

classitems.description:
Any value that is an object (excluding null).
Note that arrays, functions and all data declared with 'new' keyword is an object.
classitems.name: isObject

classitems.description:
Checks whether a given value is a string.
Note that strings declared with 'new' keyword are objects and aren't considered "string"s.
classitems.name: isString

classitems.description:
Returns true for any number (including Infinity).
Note that numbers declared with 'new' keyword are objects and aren't considered "number"s.
classitems.name: isNumber

classitems.description:
Returns true for any finite number.
Note that numbers declared with 'new' keyword are objects and aren't considered "number"s.
classitems.name: isFinite

classitems.description: Same as Array.isArray
classitems.name: isArray

classitems.description: Same as jQuery.isFunction
classitems.name: isFunction

classitems.description: Checks whether a given value is a DOM Element (Text nodes aren't included, nodeType should = 1)
classitems.name: isElement

classitems.description: Returns true only when value is NaN.
classitems.name: isNaN

classitems.description:
The arguments sent to this new function, followed by the optional arguments which were sent to 'bind', will be forwarded to func.
Similar to JS 1.8.5 bind, but with append as extra parameter.

params.name: func
params.description: Function to call

params.name: context
params.description: Set the value of the 'this' keyword to be within the function.

params.name: append
params.description: If true, appends binded arguments to any call to the new (returned) function. If false, prepend arguments.
Optional. Any number of arguments, which will be forwarded to func on call.

return.description: A new function which will have binded context and arguments.

classitems.name: bind

classitems.description:
'Left' bind
Same as bind, except that arguments are always prepended.

params.name: func
params.description: Function to bind

params.name: context
params.description: The context in which func is to be called. null would default to the global object.
Any number of arguments to be binded to func.

classitems.name: lbind

classitems.description:
'Right' bind
Same as bind, except that arguments are always appended.

params.name: func
params.description: Function to bind

params.name: context
params.description: The context in which func is to be called. null would default to the global object.
Any number of arguments to be binded to func.

classitems.name: rbind

classitems.description: Copies properties of given object(s) into a target object. Only does a shallow copy.

params.name: target
params.description: Target object into which properties of source object is copies to.

params.name: source
params.description: One or more objects from which the properties are taken from.

classitems.name: mix

classitems.description: Classical inheritence, where only prototype is inherited.

params.name: baseC
params.description: The constructor to be inherited from (the parent)

params.name: derived
params.description: The object which has a constructor and methods/properties. This will be the derived class.

props.name: constructor
props.description: Should be a function constructor of derived class.

props.name: statics
props.description: An object whose properties will be added to the derived constructor as static properties/methods.

return.description: Returns the derived constructor (the same derived.constructor).

classitems.name: extend

classitems.description:
Iterate through an array or object.
Iterates through an object's properties and calls the given callback for each (enumerable) property. Note: For arrays, this method calls Array.forEach, so for IE8 you must include lithium.ie.lang module.

params.name: obj
params.description: The array/object to iterate through.

params.name: callback
params.description: Callback function. Value, index/key and a reference to the array/object are sent as parameters (in order) to the callback.

params.name: context
params.description: Optional The value of the 'this' keyword within the callback.

classitems.name: forEach

classitems.description:
Adds properties (and methods) to a function's prototype.
Note: You won't be warned if you overwrite an existing method/property.
classitems.name: augment

classitems.description: String formatting

params.name: str
params.description: String with placeholders

params.name: arg
params.description:
If object then you can use {propertyName} as placeholder.
Else you can supply n number of args and use {argument index} as placholder

classitems.name: format

classitems.description:
Converts html string to a document fragment.
The html string and arguments are first sent to Li.format to get the final html string.

params.name: Any
params.description: number of arguments that will be passed on to Li.format. Check Li.format documentation for more information.

classitems.name: dom

classitems.description: Same as Array.slice except that it can work on array-like data types (i.e arguments, element.childNodes, NodeList...)

params.name: array
params.description: Array like values.

classitems.name: slice

classitems.description:
Generates an unique alpha-numeric identifier.
To get the same permutation as RFC-4122 use len=24.

params.name: len
params.description: Length of the UUID.

params.name: hypenate
params.description: When set to true, hyphens are added to the UUID.

classitems.name: uuid

classitems.description: Encodes &,<,> and ".
classitems.name: htmlEncode

classitems.description: Decodes string encoded by htmlEncode
classitems.name: htmlDecode

classitems.description: Call all events listeners for the given event name.

params.description: n number of arguments. These shall be directly passed onto the event listeners.

classitems.name: trigger

classitems.description:
Adds a listener.
If no parameters are specified, then this would re-enable events that were switched off by publisher.off();

params.name: object
params.description:
The event type that you want to listen to as string.
Or an object with event types and handlers as key-value pairs (with event type as the keys).
You can also subscribe for an event that has not yet been registered as an event. Hence the order of registeration is not a concern.

params.name: handler
params.description: Function that gets notfied when a event of 'eventType' gets fired. This param is used only when eventType is a string.

params.name: scope
params.description: The context in which the function should be called.

classitems.name: on

return.description: A UUID which can be used to remove the event when required.

classitems.description:
This function listens to a given publisher on the given event types,
and refires the events from itself (scope of the event fired would be this object).
This useful for chaining events.

params.name: publisher
params.description: A publisher instance.

params.name: eventTypes
params.description: Event types to listen on. If eventType is null, it listens to all events of the publisher.

classitems.name: relayEvents

classitems.description:
Remove an event listener.
If no parameters are specified, then all events are switched off till you call publisher.on().

params.name: uuidORfunc
params.description:
Can be the event listener as a Function object,
OR the UUID returned by 'on' function can also be used.

return.description: Returns true if listener was successfully removed.

classitems.name: off

classitems.description: Given a class, it inherits event types from base class.
